title: Wally Snell
text:
Walter Henry "Doc" Snell (May 19, 1889 – July 23, 1980) was a <a href="pinch-hitter">pinch-hitter</a>/<a href="catcher">catcher</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> who played briefly for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> during the season. Following this brief baseball career he became a successful <a href="mycologist">mycologist</a> who worked primarily at <a href="Brown%20University">Brown University</a> for the next 60 years.
Baseball career.
Snell was a college three-sport athlete turned scientist. Besides <a href="baseball">baseball</a>, he played <a href="American%20football">football</a> and <a href="basketball">basketball</a> at <a href="Brockton%20High%20School">Brockton High School</a>, graduating in 1907. He then attended <a href="Phillips%20Andover%20Academy">Phillips Andover Academy</a> for two years, graduating in 1909, before enrolling at <a href="Brown%20University">Brown University</a>.
At Brown, Snell was both a scholar and an athlete, as a <a href="Phi%20Beta%20Kappa%20Society">Phi Beta Kappa</a> in academics and a catcher for four years on the varsity baseball team under coach <a href="Harry%20Pattee">Harry Pattee</a>. In 1913, he was signed by the <a href="Philadelphia%20Athletics">Philadelphia Athletics</a> owner <a href="Connie%20Mack">Connie Mack</a>, but broke his hand in a game at Brown and was dealt to the Red Sox.
In a six-game career, Snell was a .250 hitter (3-for-12) with one <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">run</a> and one <a href="stolen%20base">stolen base</a> without <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBI</a> or <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s. In two catching appearances, he committed one error in 13 chances accepted for a .923 <a href="fielding%20percentage">fielding percentage</a>. Snell hit a <a href="single%20%28baseball%29">single</a> in his first major league <a href="at%20bat">at bat</a> off <a href="Cleveland%20Naps">Cleveland Naps</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> <a href="Nick%20Cullop%20%28pitcher%29">Nick Cullop</a> on August 1, 1913. He was one of five catchers the Red Sox used during the <a href="1913%20Boston%20Red%20Sox%20season">1913 season</a>.
Following his majors career, Snell continued to play some <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a> while studying for his master's degree, playing in 1914 and 1915 in the <a href="International%20League">International League</a> with the <a href="Toronto%20Maple%20Leafs%20%28International%20League%29">Toronto Maple Leafs</a> (1914) and <a href="Rochester%20Red%20Wings">Rochester Hustlers</a> (1915), and for the <a href="Manchester-by-the-Sea%2C%20Massachusetts">Manchester</a> team of the <a href="New%20England%20League">New England League</a> (1915), becoming a <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a> in his last baseball season.
Doctoral career.
After receiving his master's degree from Brown in 1915, Snell began to pursue his doctoral studies in 1916 at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin">University of Wisconsin</a>. He earned a Ph.D. degree in <a href="botany">botany</a> and went on to a distinguished career as a college professor and athletic coach both in baseball and football at Brown University for 39 years. In the summer of 1923, he managed the <a href="Hyannis%20Harbor%20Hawks">Hyannis</a> town team in the <a href="Cape%20Cod%20Baseball%20League">Cape Cod Baseball League</a>.
After retiring as a professor in 1959, he had written numerous professional papers on research in his field, published in scientific journals such as "<a href="Mycologia">Mycologia</a>" and "Phytopathology". His research delved in areas as diverse as forest tree diseases, decay in building timbers, toxicity of <a href="creosote">creosote</a>s to <a href="wood-decay%20fungus">wood-destroying fungi</a>, language of <a href="mycology">mycology</a>, and <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomy</a> of <a href="bolete">bolete</a>s and <a href="hydnum">hydnum</a>s (types of mushrooms and fungi).
Snell died at the age of 91 in <a href="Providence%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Providence, Rhode Island</a>.
